Award.AwardTitle: NEB: Novel Quantum Switches Using Heterogeneous Atomically Layered Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is awarded under the Nanoelectronics for 2020 and Beyond competition, with support by multiple Directorates and Divisions at the National Science Foundation as well as by the Nanoelectronics Research Initiative of the Semiconductor Research Corporation.

TECHNICAL: The search for high-performance electronic switches operating at low power dissipation has generated many concepts that go beyond the control of charge flow in traditional semiconductor device structures. These novel devices are based on the use of alternative state variables, including the characteristics of single-particle quantum systems, such as spin, pseudospin, and carrier wave-function phase, and the characteristics of correlated many-body quantum systems, such as excitons and exciton condensates. The goal of this project is to develop the basis for transformative technology that would be made possible by the availability of high-performance electronic devices employing such quantum state variables, rather than traditional semi-classical transport of charge. To this end, a team of investigators at Columbia University and University of Florida is devoted to the fabrication, characterization, and theoretical analysis of such quantum switches. The research exploits recent technological advances in the synthesis of atomically thin layers of van der Waals solids and heterostructures formed from combinations of such layered materials. The potential of this approach is exemplified by the excellent electrical characteristics exhibited by heterostructures of atomically thin layers of graphene and hexagonal boron nitride. In this project, devices are built from such well-developed material systems, where the primary fabrication challenges involve precise control over geometry and interface cleanliness. The key research components of the project are as follows: (i) The assembly and fabrication of atomically thin heterostructure devices based on the co-lamination of van der Waals materials, atomic-layer deposition processes, and advanced patterning techniques; (ii) the analysis of distinctive quantum coherent transport processes in weakly coupled layered heterojunction device structures by electrical and optical measurements; (iii) the establishment of new state variables based on quantum coherence; and (iv) the demonstration, characterization, and theoretical modeling of switching devices based on novel state variables. Devices resulting from this research effort promise performance with respect to switching speed and energy dissipation that significantly exceeds the limits imposed by conventional semiconductor device technology.

NON-TECHNICAL: The development of the new electronic devices based on low-dimensional functional material platforms opens important directions in both fundamental and applied research. The availability of practical high-performance, low-energy switching devices is of great significance for the continued advancement of electronics and the associated information technology industry. Thus, the demonstration of devices based on new switching principles has the potential for broad technological impact. The diverse capabilities of the team also significantly enhance the educational opportunities for students and postdocs at Columbia and at collaborating institutions. The highly interdisciplinary research carried out in this project provides cutting-edge training for graduate students and postdocs, as well as for undergraduate students. The team integrates research activities with educational efforts by offering new lecture and laboratory courses, as well as modifying existing ones. The team also undertakes broader educational outreach through sponsorship of summer research projects for high school students. Significant efforts are made toward K-12 outreach by training of highly motivated high school students, and by enhancing interactions with local K-12 educators to introduce front-line research to students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we sought to explore ways in which novel two-dimensional (2D) materials could be used to create new type of nano-electronic devices.  These materials include graphene – a single atomic sheet of carbon which acts as a metallic conductor – as well as semiconductors such as molybdenum disulfide and insulators such as boron nitride. All of these materials can be ‘exfoliated’ from bulk crystals onto silicon substrates using Scotch tape, providing a wide variety of materials that can be isolated as atomically thin (and therefore two-dimensional) sheets. These materials offer new potential for creating electronic devices that behave differently from conventional transistors made from bulk semiconductors (e.g. silicon). A grand challenge for this field of work is to find ways to create nano-scale electronic switches that are more energy-efficient than the transistors used in today’s computers. This would allow for large increases in computing speed as well as a reduction in power consumption.

 

 As one example shown in the attached figure, we simulated theoretically the behavior of a device known as a tunneling field effect transistor (TFET), in which current flows between two layers of different semiconductors, and can be turned on and off by changing the potential in one of the layers using an external ‘gate’ electrode. Our simulations confirmed that, in the ideal case, a TFET composed of two atomically thin semiconductors – MoTe2 and MoS2 – can indeed outperform conventional transistors.

 

In order to build devices like the TFET, we needed to first develop techniques for creating layered ‘heterostructures’ -- i.e. stacks made from different materials – without contaminating the materials or their interfaces. We demonstrated that two-dimensional materials can be used to ‘pick up’ each other to create heterostructures that are remarkably free of contamination between layers. Using this technique, we studied basic electrical transport properties of two materials (graphene and MoS2) encapsulated by insulating boron nitride (BN), which provides an ultra-clean environment. We also isolated an atomically thin superconductor (NbSe2) with protection by BN to prevent oxidation, and found a new type of superconducting phase that had been theoretically predicted but never observed.  Finally, we created the most fundamental type of electronic device, known as a p-n junction, by stacking semiconducting MoS2 and WSe2 on top of each other. P-n junctions are a basic building block of electronics, and our measurements provided an understanding of how they behave when the two semiconducting layers are atomically thin.

 

In parallel with these efforts to create and study electronic devices, we studied the structural and optical properties of the 2D materials themselves. We used scanning tunneling microscopy to measure the bandgaps of 2D semiconductors and study the properties of defects such as atomic vacancies. We used optical spectroscopy to study a wide variety of properties of these materials, particularly to understand the nature of excitons (bound states of electrons and holes) which have large binding energies in low-dimensional materials. Because excitons are conceptually similar to hydrogen atoms, they also show a series of excited states like the famous Rydberg series that provided the early understanding of the structure of the atom. In the case of 2D materials, we able to measure the ‘Rydberg’ series for excitons. Interestingly, the 2D excitonic states are not found at exactly the energies predicted by a Rydberg model, because different states are more or less sensitive to the properties of the surrounding environment.  

 

Seven PhD students, five postdoctoral researchers, and two undergraduates participated in this research. They gained valuable experience in interdisciplinary research including theory, materials synthesis, electronic, and optical measurements.

 

We worked with the Semiconductor Research Cooperation (SRC), one of the sponsors of NRI/NEB program, to introduce our results to members of the semiconductor industry. This included talks at joint meetings and participation in an e-Workshop series.
